content: Is anyone actually capable of paying attention today?
:wave:
@Jacob Lifshay and @Caleb Zulawski ?
stirs drink Just us, it seems. ^^;
Alright
First, congrats to all the gang on the stdsimd merge to stdlib.
Where can I catchup quickly on the current state of affairs and beasts to tackle and discuss?
starts to dust off ye ol‚Äô PRs

I think a lot of our current issues are documented in our issue tracker still, remarkably.
Implicitly, what came up, and what a lot of current PRs are about addressing, is uh... well, our r/rust reddit thread lol.
Oh bother
I didn‚Äôt want to bring that up, but what‚Äôs the holdup on the technical side of that?

Critiques included "docs bad" (I knew that, but that's why portable-simd#191, portable-simd#195, portable-simd#198, portable-simd#199).
https://www.reddit.com/r/rust/comments/qucind/stdsimd_is_now_available_on_nightly/
On which?
:sweat_smile:
Oh, nevermind - I mixed up the spicy resdit threads today, lemme brb.

We also need to handle the way the crate's features are divvied up in a way that lets std use other things.
We need a lot more casts, which will be handled partly by the former, and partly by fixing simd_cast in the codegen backend.
OK.
Oh, that reddit thread could have been worse.
I didn‚Äôt know that rust devs would answer on reddit. It‚Äôs not common in Julia but ok.
I avoid it tbh.

But yeah that's why I drafted this, https://github.com/rust-lang/portable-simd/pull/195
this https://github.com/rust-lang/portable-simd/pull/198
and this https://github.com/rust-lang/portable-simd/pull/199
Neat.
and yes if you want you can resume with https://github.com/rust-lang/portable-simd/pull/128 ^^;
10-4 roger roger
How where you able to calculate that the docs were 20kb4/MB lighter after the first fix? Using tokei or dust or something like that?****
cargo doc --no-deps and examining the filesize of the offending page
switch branches, rebuild, etc.
It is almost entirely the one page that needs to be cleaned up: everything rides on struct.Simd.html
Sweet, thanks for the tip.
Oh, I really like the trait driven arithmetic to constrain the macro polymorphism. Feels very Rusty.
Yeah, 90% of the debate atm is which constraints to use.
Ah. Thank you for coming. :upside_down:

So I'm guessing

  1. Cleaning up docs (including tutorials)
  2. Arithmetic trait API for reduced bloat
    are the current "workable" tasks with
    i) don't bork inference with the new traits
    ii) worry about masks
    as punts for later
Thanks for the talk! :wave:
More or less yes. There's probably some misc functions we could be implementing like powi still, also, and if you happen to be familiar with LLVM codegen, you could take the task to fix up simd_cast.
Gotcha. You mean LLVM codegen via the Rust backend, or raw LLVM C++?

Our Rust backend. :D
which
mostly, uh, for the SIMD stuff,
emits LLVM IR directly.
https://github.com/rust-lang/portable-simd/issues/14 is our still-unimplemented instruction set.
Oh, I dig those...
Sorry, didn't have internet
No updates from me other than I plan on continuing to review all the PRs
Generally like the direction those are going
I don't think I have the chops to help the inference issue but by golly do I support not removing splatting.
My understanding of the type/trait system is that by having stricter bounds it will strengthen opportunities for inference by disqualifying inferring Simd more often.
If absolutely necessary we can kick the tires on the type inference engine. It's not like we haven't already been touching rustc_typeck
Hopefully the added heuristics aren‚Äôt that much more work.
just gonna commit a full-on bidirectional typing engine to the compiler nbd
no lie at some point rewriting the Julia type inference algo in Rust is an interesting experiment.
But that‚Äôs a talk for another channel and day üòÖ
sorry, I got distracted by other stuff, no updates from me
